articles.headline: A Policy-Making Mystery in the Renminbi’s Decline
articles.snippet: Observers question whether the drop in the value of China’s currency to its lowest levels since 2012 is a result of central bank intervention or a weakening economy.
articles.abstract: Observers question whether the drop in the value of China’s currency to its lowest levels since 2012 is a result of central bank intervention or a weakening economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As President Obama visits Asia in a bid to shore up American alliances, he faces an emerging challenge from the region’s behemoth, China, whose currency has experienced a gradual but unrelenting decline over the last 10 days.

articles.headline: Donating, and Making Sure the Money Is Put to Work
articles.snippet: Researching a charity does not guarantee your money will end up doing what you want it to. Some organizations, though, are working toward more transparency.
articles.abstract: Researching a charity does not guarantee your money will end up doing what you want it to. Some organizations, though, are working toward more transparency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each year, we file a report card on our financial lives. It tells us what we earned, a bit about what we saved, some details on what we own and often includes a tally of our generosity. True, most people don’t read their tax returns this way, but it’s helpful to think of them as a conversation starter and a guide to what we can do better next year.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Shrinking Profit Sets Off a Seismic Shock to Its Shares
articles.snippet: For a second quarter in a row, the Internet retailer’s stock fell sharply after its earnings report, suggesting that investors may be growing wary.
articles.abstract: For a second quarter in a row, the Internet retailer’s stock fell sharply after its earnings report, suggesting that investors may be growing wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is a 20-year honeymoon coming to an end?

articles.headline: Vow of Freedom of Religion Goes Unkept in Egypt
articles.snippet: The architects of the military takeover promised religious tolerance and pluralism, but nine months later not much has changed.
articles.abstract: The architects of the military takeover promised religious tolerance and pluralism, but nine months later not much has changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The architects of the military takeover in Egypt promised a new era of tolerance and pluralism when they deposed President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood last summer.

articles.headline: Private Citizen Bloomberg on Philanthropy
articles.snippet: When it comes to giving away his fortune, Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, says he seeks causes others may have overlooked and ways to test new ideas.
articles.abstract: When it comes to giving away his fortune, Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, says he seeks causes others may have overlooked and ways to test new ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg has given billions of dollars to charity and plans to give tens of billions more. His foundation, Bloomberg Philanthropies, has been ranked among the most innovative organizations in the country. And he has been willing to finance programs that could be controversial if they failed — like teaching high school graduates in Tanzania to perform appendectomies and cesarean sections.

articles.headline: A Consensus in Washington, but No Action
articles.snippet: The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has gone nowhere, even though Democrats and Republicans, Congress and the White House, agree it is essential and overdue.
articles.abstract: The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has gone nowhere, even though Democrats and Republicans, Congress and the White House, agree it is essential and overdue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has friends in all the right places.

articles.headline: In Land That Values Ivory, Wild Elephants Find a Safe Haven
articles.snippet: Government protections are helping Asian elephant numbers rise, but forests are rapidly giving way to rubber and other cash crops.
articles.abstract: Government protections are helping Asian elephant numbers rise, but forests are rapidly giving way to rubber and other cash crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: XISHUANGBANNA, China — At a time when tens of thousands of elephants across Africa are being slaughtered to feed the Chinese appetite for ivory, it turns out the best place to be a wild elephant may be here in the tropical forests of southwest China.

articles.headline: European Firms Seek to Minimize Russia Sanctions
articles.snippet: As businesses, particularly in the energy sector, campaign to maintain ties with Moscow, the world’s seven wealthiest nations said on Friday that they would impose additional sanctions on Russia resulting from its military action in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: As businesses, particularly in the energy sector, campaign to maintain ties with Moscow, the world’s seven wealthiest nations said on Friday that they would impose additional sanctions on Russia resulting from its military action in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With the showdown over Ukraine escalating and President Obama warning Moscow of a tough new round of sanctions, Russia and its allies in the European private sector are conducting a separate campaign to ensure that they can maintain their deep and longstanding economic ties even if the Kremlin orders further military action.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: As Parents Make Their Own Baby Food, Industry Tries to Adapt
articles.snippet: Sales of commercially prepared baby food have been steadily falling since 2005 as parents take a do-it-yourself approach.
articles.abstract: Sales of commercially prepared baby food have been steadily falling since 2005 as parents take a do-it-yourself approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dylan DeNeve of Brooklyn dined on homemade baby food of vegetable purées, delicately seasoned with leeks, red peppers, cumin and thyme, prepared by her mother, Alexandra, a lawyer. In Atlanta, Wes and Hadley Stewart enjoyed homemade mashed-up kale, butternut squash and ancient grains.

articles.headline: A Walmart Fortune, Spreading Charter Schools
articles.snippet: The foundation led by the family that built Walmart has spent more than $1 billion on some of the fastest-growing, and most divisive, trends in education.
articles.abstract: The foundation led by the family that built Walmart has spent more than $1 billion on some of the fastest-growing, and most divisive, trends in education.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DC Prep operates four charter schools here with 1,200 students in preschool through eighth grade. The schools, whose students are mostly poor and black, are among the highest performing in Washington. Last year, DC Prep’s flagship middle school earned the best test scores among local charter schools, far outperforming the average of the city’s traditional neighborhood schools as well.

articles.headline: Sainthood for 2 Predecessors Allows Pope to Straddle Divide
articles.snippet: John XXIII, revered by Roman Catholic liberals, and John Paul II, beloved by conservatives, will be recognized as saints at a Mass on Sunday as Pope Francis pushes his own vision of a church under a big tent.
articles.abstract: John XXIII, revered by Roman Catholic liberals, and John Paul II, beloved by conservatives, will be recognized as saints at a Mass on Sunday as Pope Francis pushes his own vision of a church under a big tent.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope John XXIII was the rotund Italian pontiff with a common touch, who told jokes, embraced the poor and became beloved as “the Good Pope.” To many liberal Catholics, he is still revered for the Second Vatican Council, the landmark event of the 1960s that sought to move the Roman Catholic Church into the modern age.

articles.headline: From Outside or Inside, the Deck Looks Stacked
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Warren’s new book sees a lamentable but enduring theme in Washington: special treatment for Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Warren’s new book sees a lamentable but enduring theme in Washington: special treatment for Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The game is rigged and the American people know that. They get it right down to their toes.”

articles.headline: Afghan Voters Signaling a Turn
articles.snippet: In preliminary results released Saturday, Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai’s and an ardent supporter of the United States, won 45 percent of the votes in the presidential election, but not enough to avoid a runoff.
articles.abstract: In preliminary results released Saturday, Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai’s and an ardent supporter of the United States, won 45 percent of the votes in the presidential election, but not enough to avoid a runoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai and an ardent supporter of the United States, emerged Saturday as the clear front-runner in Afghanistan’s presidential election.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Where Vapor Comes Sweeping Down the Plain
articles.snippet: Regulators may be starting to circle, but in Oklahoma, the e-cigarette industry is going full steam ahead.
articles.abstract: Regulators may be starting to circle, but in Oklahoma, the e-cigarette industry is going full steam ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nick Whitson, who is 32 and covered with enigmatic tattoos — the number 13, an upside-down cross — stood in front of a table scattered with dozens of bottles of colorful liquids and a handful of syringes, preparing to mix Trevor Curren his usual.

articles.headline: Governor With Eye on 2016 Finds His Rise Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a potential Republican contender for president, has steadily gained prominence assisted by his knack for recognizing and seizing political opportunities.
articles.abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a potential Republican contender for president, has steadily gained prominence assisted by his knack for recognizing and seizing political opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: STURTEVANT, Wis. — Scott Walker is nothing if not consistent.

articles.headline: How a Gulf Settlement That BP Once Hailed Became Its Target
articles.snippet: In ads, interviews and court filings, BP officials have insisted that their good intentions in settling the 2010 Gulf of Mexico spill were being hijacked by greedy lawyers and underhanded claimants.
articles.abstract: In ads, interviews and court filings, BP officials have insisted that their good intentions in settling the 2010 Gulf of Mexico spill were being hijacked by greedy lawyers and underhanded claimants.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Four years ago the Deepwater Horizon oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 men, spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and staining, seemingly indelibly, the image of BP, the international energy giant responsible for the well.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Sanctions Revive Search for Secret Putin Fortune
articles.snippet: President Obama’s response to the Ukraine crisis, while derided by critics as slow and weak, has reinvigorated a 15-year global hunt for the Russian leader’s hidden wealth.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s response to the Ukraine crisis, while derided by critics as slow and weak, has reinvigorated a 15-year global hunt for the Russian leader’s hidden wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration imposed sanctions on individual Russians last month in response to Moscow’s armed intervention in Ukraine, one of the targets was a longtime part-owner of a commodities trading company called the Gunvor Group.

articles.headline: A European Energy Executive’s Delicate Dance Over Ukraine
articles.snippet: The Italian energy giant ENI is the biggest distributor of Russian gas in Europe, but its chief is risking Moscow’s wrath by trying to help Kiev.
articles.abstract: The Italian energy giant ENI is the biggest distributor of Russian gas in Europe, but its chief is risking Moscow’s wrath by trying to help Kiev.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European executives, especially in the energy industry, have been notably wary of ratcheting up economic tensions with Russia over the Ukraine crisis. They see their business interests as too intertwined to risk stiffer sanctions.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and James Kanter

articles.headline: Few Consumers Are Buying Premise of Mobile Wallets
articles.snippet: While numerous solutions are in the market, none have won widespread adoption, as consumers are either unaware of the option — or unimpressed by it.
articles.abstract: While numerous solutions are in the market, none have won widespread adoption, as consumers are either unaware of the option — or unimpressed by it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Millions of Americans use smartphones for tasks like hailing a taxi or checking in for a flight. But for buying something in a store? That mostly remains a tech entrepreneur’s dream.

articles.headline: New Challenges Chip Away at Cable’s Pillar of Profit
articles.snippet: A future where consumers will be able to assemble an à la carte menu of entertainment suddenly seems much closer.
articles.abstract: A future where consumers will be able to assemble an à la carte menu of entertainment suddenly seems much closer.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, cable television has been an almost magical source of profits, in large part because of the bundle, the packaging of channels that compels subscribers to buy a lot of programming they never watch.

articles.headline: Despite Big Ambitions, New York’s Tech Scene Is Still Starting Up
articles.snippet: While the city’s new tech firms continue to attract plenty of venture capital, Silicon Alley has a long way to go before it rivals the Valley.
articles.abstract: While the city’s new tech firms continue to attract plenty of venture capital, Silicon Alley has a long way to go before it rivals the Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: Predicting that your city will be the next Silicon Valley is simple. But actually making it the next Silicon Valley is something else entirely — as New York is slowly finding out.

articles.headline: Soured Mortgages Attract Institutional Dollars
articles.snippet: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.
articles.abstract: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Harder Line on Russia Than European Allies
articles.snippet: The White House has become entangled in a debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow, while pro-Russian forces in Ukraine continue to defy demands.
articles.abstract: The White House has become entangled in a debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow, while pro-Russian forces in Ukraine continue to defy demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama and his national security team struggle to increase pressure on Russia over its intervention in Ukraine, they have become entangled in a tense debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies more reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and C. J. Chivers

articles.headline: One Therapist, $4 Million in 2012 Medicare Billing
articles.snippet: Physical therapy is a big recipient of national Medicare dollars — and physical therapists in Brooklyn are among the biggest billers of all, government data indicates.
articles.abstract: Physical therapy is a big recipient of national Medicare dollars — and physical therapists in Brooklyn are among the biggest billers of all, government data indicates.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few miles from the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn stands an outpost of what, on paper, is a giant of American medicine.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: In Venezuela, Protesters Point to Their Scars
articles.snippet: President Nicolás Maduro, fearing efforts to overthrow him, said he held the opposition responsible for the violence that, by some accounts, had claimed more than 40 lives.
articles.abstract: President Nicolás Maduro, fearing efforts to overthrow him, said he held the opposition responsible for the violence that, by some accounts, had claimed more than 40 lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Venezuela — Clipso Martínez was shot at such close range by a soldier at a protest that his surgeon said he had to remove pieces of the plastic shotgun shell buried in his leg, along with the shards of keys Mr. Martínez had in his pocket, shattered by the blast.

articles.headline: Gay Rights Push Shifts Its Focus South and West
articles.snippet: In a drive to win more rights and protections, gay advocates are setting their sights on Southern and Western states, where the movement’s rapid progress has largely eluded gay men and lesbians.
articles.abstract: In a drive to win more rights and protections, gay advocates are setting their sights on Southern and Western states, where the movement’s rapid progress has largely eluded gay men and lesbians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The country’s leading gay rights groups and donors, after a decade focused on legalizing same-sex marriage, are embarking on a major drive to win more basic civil rights and workplace protections in Southern and Western states where the rapid progress of the movement has largely eluded millions of gay men and lesbians.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Bank of America Finds a Mistake: $4 Billion Less Capital
articles.snippet: After Bank of America reported its error, the the Federal Reserve required the bank to suspend a share buyback and a planned increase in its quarterly dividend.
articles.abstract: After Bank of America reported its error, the the Federal Reserve required the bank to suspend a share buyback and a planned increase in its quarterly dividend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:03 p.m. | Bank of America disclosed on Monday that it had made a significant error in the way it calculates a crucial measure of its financial health, suffering another blow to its effort to shake its troubled history.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Michael Corkery
